title: How to Carry Surfboards on the Roof of a Vehicle

steps.title: Securely attach racks to the vehicle.
steps.content: Securely attach racks to the vehicle. If the racks are so-called "soft racks," they should consist of more than just a web strap that wraps around the vehicle.

steps.title: Straps that wrap around the rack and surfboard must be inspected for worn or weak spots.
steps.content: Straps that wrap around the rack and surfboard must be inspected for worn or weak spots. Buckles on the straps should be the cam-spring type and not d-ring style. No-Rust zinc buckles are preferred.

steps.title: Place the surfboard with the fin(s) up and forward on the rack.
steps.content: Place the surfboard with the fin(s) up and forward on the rack. This reduces "lift" and the surfboard fins will act as a "stop" to prevent the board from sliding backwards off the rack.

steps.title: Wrap the straps through the side-rails (around the cross-bars) of the rack and over the top of the surfboard(s) then around the cross-bars on the other side.
steps.content: Wrap the straps through the side-rails (around the cross-bars) of the rack and over the top of the surfboard(s) then around the cross-bars on the other side. Make sure the strap buckle is not on the rail of the surfboard. Each strap should cross the board twice. Repeat for other cross-bar. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Give the board a solid "shake" to make sure the board will not shift in the rack.
steps.content: Give the board a solid "shake" to make sure the board will not shift in the rack. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Always tie-off excess strap.
steps.content: Always tie-off excess strap. Never let it flap in the wind.

steps.title: Be careful not to over-tighten straps as this can damage surfboards.
steps.content: Be careful not to over-tighten straps as this can damage surfboards. [3] X Research source
